description: pic - compile pictures for troff or TeX

global_flags.description: --version  show  version information; all exit afterward.
Recognize .PS, .PE, .PF, and .PY even when followed by a charac‐ ter other than space or newline.
Draw  all  lines  using  the \D escape sequence.  GNU pic always does this.
Operate  in safer mode; sh commands are ignored.  This mode, en‐ abled by default, can be useful when operating on  untrustworthy input.
This  is  unnecessary because the troff output generated by GNU pic is device-indepen‐ dent.
Operate in unsafe mode; sh commands are interpreted.

Be  more compatible with tpic; implies -t.  Lines beginning with \ are not passed through transparently.  Lines beginning with  . are  passed through with the initial . changed to \.  A line be‐ ginning with .ps is given special treatment:  it  takes  an  op‐ tional integer argument specifying the line thickness (pen size) in  milliinches;  a  missing argument restores the previous line thickness; the default line thickness  is  8  milliinches.   The line thickness thus specified takes effect only when a non-nega‐ tive  line  thickness  has  not  been  specified  by  use of the thickness attribute or by setting the linethick variable.

Don't use groff extensions to the troff drawing commands.  Spec‐ ify this option if a postprocessor you're using doesn't  support these  extensions,  described in groff_out(5).  This option also causes pic not to use zero-length lines to draw  dots  in  troff mode.
In TeX mode, draw dots using zero-length lines.

subcommands.name: A
subcommands.description: bare  expression, expr, is acceptable as an attribute; it is equiva‐ lent to dir expr, where dir is the current direction.  For example

subcommands.name: Boxes
subcommands.description: can have slanted sides.  This effectively changes the shape of a box from a rectangle to an arbitrary parallelogram.  The  xslanted  and yslanted attributes specify the x and y offset of the box's upper right corner from its default position.

subcommands.name: Characters
subcommands.description: that  are invalid as input to GNU troff (see the groff Tex‐ info manual or groff_char(7) for a list) are rejected even in TeX mode.

subcommands.name: Concatenate
subcommands.description: and  write  arguments  to the standard error stream followed by a newline.  Each arg must be an expression, a  posi‐ tion, or text.  This is useful for debugging.

subcommands.name: Evaluate
subcommands.description: expr;  if it is non-zero then do if-true, otherwise do if-false.  X can be any character not occurring in  if-true.   Y can be any character not occurring in if-false.

subcommands.name: For
subcommands.description: bitmapped  graphic  formats, you should use pstopnm; the resulting (intermediate) pnm(5) file can  be  then  converted  to  virtually  any graphics format using the tools of the netpbm package.

subcommands.name: In
subcommands.description: (almost  all) places where a quoted text string can be used, an ex‐ pression of the form

subcommands.name: There
subcommands.description: is  no  limit to the depth to which blocks can be examined.  For example,

subcommands.name: To
subcommands.description: change  the  name  of the vbox in TeX mode, set the pseudo-variable figname (which is actually a specially parsed command)  within  a  pic‐ ture.  Example:

subcommands.name: are
subcommands.description: equivalent.  The commands to be performed for each line can also be taken from a macro defined earlier by giving the name of the macro as the argument to thru.  The argument after  thru  is looked up as a macro name first; if not defined, its first char‐ acter is interpreted as a delimiter.

subcommands.name: groff
subcommands.description: itself  does  not  provide direct conversion into other graphics file formats.  But there are lots of possibilities if you first  trans‐ form  your picture into PostScript® format using the groff option -Tps. Since this ps-file lacks BoundingBox information it is not very  useful by  itself,  but  it may be fed into other conversion programs, usually named ps2other or pstoother or the like.  Moreover, the PostScript  in‐ terpreter  Ghostscript (gs(1)) has built-in graphics conversion devices that are called with the option

subcommands.name: must
subcommands.description: already be defined, and expr will be assigned to var with‐ out creating a variable local to the current  block.   (By  con‐ trast,  =  defines var in the current block if it is not already defined there, and then changes the value in the  current  block only.)  For example, .PS x = 3 y = 3 [ x := 5 y = 5 ] print x   y .PE writes 5 3 to the standard error stream.

subcommands.name: ps2eps
subcommands.description: is  available  from  CTAN  mirrors,  e.g.,  ftp://ftp.dante.de/ tex-archive/support/ps2eps/

subcommands.name: the
subcommands.description: picture.   If the width of zero is specified the width will be ig‐ nored in computing the scaling factor for the picture.   GNU  pic  will always  scale  a picture by the same amount vertically as well as hori‐ zontally.  This is different from DWB 2.0 pic which may scale a picture by a different amount vertically than horizontally if a height is spec‐ ified.
